(非律師版)
Dear Sir,

I refer to your reply which indicates that all conduct investigation of the Law Society is to be held in confidence. Meanwhile, I also understand that:-

1. the Law Society is statutorily empowered under the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159 of The Laws of Hong Kong) to investigate and refer allegations of professional misconduct to the Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal, and to intervene a solicitor's practice in cases of dishonesty, bankruptcy or other causes;
2. pursuant to Article (18)(d) of the Articles of Association of the Law Society, the Law Society shall have the power to investigate any charge of misconduct against any solicitor (whether a Member or not) or employee of a solicitor and to institute and (if the Council think fit) prosecute any disciplinary proceedings;

3. pursuant to Point 9 of the "Notes to Parties to a Complaint" published on the website of the Law Society (the "Note"), “Either party to a complaint may seek a review of the decision of an Investigation Committee by referring the matter to the Standing Committee on Compliance”

The subject complaint involves significant issues of public interests. Members of the public are entitled to know whether the powers of the Law Society provided under the statutory regime and its Articles have been exercised properly.

Being a complainant I shall also be entitled to seek a review of the decision of the Investigation Committee, pursuant to Point 9 of the Note.

Please therefore enlighten me as to your justifications of refusing to inform the complainant of the progress and/or the result of the investigation. In these circumstances, (1) how would a complainant be able to learn about the fact that the investigation and/or disciplinary proceedings have been commenced/came to its end? (2) how would he be able to apply for a review of the decision, if any? (3) how does a secret investigation enhance public confidence?

I hereby request the Law Society to keep myself informed of the progress of the investigation and the result of the same.

Your prompt reply is much appreciated.

Yours Faithfully,

(律師版)
Dear Sir,

I refer to your reply which indicates that all conduct investigation of the Law Society is to be held in confidence. Meanwhile, I also understand that:-

1. the Law Society is statutorily empowered under the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159 of The Laws of Hong Kong) to investigate and refer allegations of professional misconduct to the Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal, and to intervene a solicitor's practice in cases of dishonesty, bankruptcy or other causes;
2. pursuant to Article (18)(d) of the Articles of Association of the Law Society, the Law Society shall have the power to investigate any charge of misconduct against any solicitor (whether a Member or not) or employee of a solicitor and to institute and (if the Council think fit) prosecute any disciplinary proceedings;

3. pursuant to Point 9 of the "Notes to Parties to a Complaint" published on the website of the Law Society (the "Note") as well as Chapter 15 of the Guide to Professional Conduct published by the Law Society, “Either party to a complaint may seek a review of the decision of an Investigation Committee by referring the matter to the Standing Committee on Compliance”

Being a complainant I shall also be entitled to seek a review of the decision of the Investigation Committee, pursuant to Point 9 of the Note.

Being a member of the Law Society I shall also be entitled to be assured that the Law Society is operating in compliance with its Articles.

The subject complaint involves significant issues of public interests. Members of the public are entitled to know whether the powers of the Law Society provided under the statutory regime and its Articles have been exercised properly.

Please therefore enlighten me as to your justifications of refusing to inform the complainant of the progress and/or the result of the investigation. In these circumstances, (1) how would a complainant be able to learn about the fact that the investigation and/or disciplinary proceedings have been commenced/came to its end? (2) how would he be able to apply for a review of the decision, if any? (3) how does a secret investigation enhance public confidence and promote the reputation of the legal industry?

I hereby request the Law Society to keep myself informed of the progress of the investigation and the result of the same.

Your prompt reply is much appreciated.

Yours Faithfully,
